title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes individual investment accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to individual investment accounts established for their benefit. Individual investment accounts are trusts created for the exclusive benefit of an individual, with specific requirements for contributions and trustees. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to individual investment accounts meeting specific requirements, including trustees being banks or approved persons, no investment in collectibles, and no commingling of assets. Contributions are deemed made on the last day. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" specifies that contributions to individual investment accounts must meet certain requirements, including no investment in collectibles and no commingling of assets. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year. Distributions from these accounts are generally included in gross income unless they qualify as a first-time homebuyer distribution. The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" states that distributions from individual investment accounts are taxable unless they qualify as a first-time homebuyer distribution. A qualified first-time homebuyer distribution is a payment received by a first-time homebuyer from an individual investment account and used for qualified acquisition costs within 120 days. A first-time homebuyer can receive a distribution from an individual investment account to pay for qualified acquisition costs for a principal residence. The total amount of qualified first-time homebuyer distributions cannot exceed $20,000, and the basis of the residence will be reduced by the distribution amount. The transfer of an individual's interest in an individual investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not considered a taxable transfer. The account will be treated as belonging to the spouse, and any subsequent transactions will be under their ownership. The transfer of an individual's interest in an individual investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not taxable. The account will be treated as belonging to the spouse and will be exempt from taxation unless it no longer qualifies as an individual investment account. Individual investment accounts are exempt from taxation unless they no longer qualify as such. If an individual engages in a prohibited transaction, the account will lose its exemption status. If the individual for whom the individual investment account is established engages in a prohibited transaction, the account will cease to be an individual investment account and be treated as distributing all its assets. On the first day of any taxable year, paragraph (1) of subsection (c) is applied as if there were a distribution equal to the fair market value of all assets in the account. If the account is used as security for a loan, that portion is treated as distributed. Rollover contributions are not subject to subsection (c)(1). The $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) will be increased for taxable years after 1998 based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Rollover contributions from individual investment accounts must be made within 60 days to another account for the same individual's benefit. Beginning in a calendar year after 1998, the $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the increased dollar amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Custodial accounts will be treated as trusts if the assets are held by a bank or another person approved by the Secretary. The custodial accounts will be treated as trusts if the assets are held by a bank or another approved person. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary regarding contributions, distributions, and other matters as required by regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income for such accounts. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary as required by regulations. Deductions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income for such accounts, and individual investment accounts are exempt from estate tax. SEC. 2046. INDIVIDUAL INVESTMENT ACCOUNTS. Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are not subject to Section 1014. A special rule exempts individuals from tax on prohibited transactions related to these accounts if the account ceases to be an individual investment account. Individual investment accounts are exempt from tax on prohibited transactions if the account ceases to be an individual investment account. This exemption applies to transactions taxable under this section. The tax code is amended to include provisions for individual investment accounts, failure to provide reports on these accounts, and adjustments to the basis of residence acquired through the use of such accounts. The tax code is amended to include provisions for individual investment accounts and adjustments to the basis of residence acquired through the use of such accounts. The tax code is amended to include provisions for individual investment accounts and disclaimers. Effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 1997.
